executive_summary: Over the past five years, cider producers have struggled to sustain the explosive growth in demand from previous years amid volatile economic conditions and heightened competition from alternative beverages. The rise of hard seltzers and canned cocktails encroached on cider sales as younger drinkers sought new flavors. During the pandemic, cider producers benefited from their dependence on off-premise sales channels as alcohol retail sales soared. Industry-wide revenue has been growing at an average annualized 3.2% over the past five years and is expected to total $628.1 million in 2024 when revenue will jump by an estimated 8.9%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Craft Cider Continues to Expand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: There's been a significant rise in craft cider brands, embracing diverse flavors and small-batch productions. Consumer demand for flavorful alternatives to mainstream beverages is fueling this surge. Many craft cider producers are opening taprooms and brewpubs, enhancing brand visibility and providing immersive experiences to enthusiasts. Cider brands resonate with ecologically aware consumers by focusing on local sourcing and sustainable practices.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Innovation and Experimentation Run the Show
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Craft cider producers are experimenting with diverse and unique flavor profiles, including fruit-infused, barrel-aged and botanical ciders. Collaborations with other beverage producers, like wineries and distilleries, have produced innovative cider blends. Seasonal and limited-edition releases add to the variety and create anticipation among cider lovers. Health-conscious consumers and designated drivers are catered to by expanding non-alcoholic and low-alcohol cider offerings.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Health and Wellness Influence the Cider Market
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Aligning with health trends, cider producers are introducing low-sugar and low-calorie options to the market. Incorporating functional ingredients into ciders appeals to health-conscious consumers seeking wellness benefits from their beverages. The naturally gluten-free property of cider makes it an appealing choice for those with gluten sensitivities or on gluten-free diets. Cider producers respond to consumer preference for transparency and clean labeling by highlighting natural ingredients and production methods on packaging and marketing.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Cider producers are increasingly using eco-friendly packaging options. There's an investment in renewable energy sources like solar and wind power. Waste reduction is a focus, with practices like composting pomace and efficient water management. Producers engage local communities in environmental stewardship programs to strengthen bonds and promote brand loyalty.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Cider Producers are Expanding Their Horizons
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Producers are diversifying their portfolio to include alternative beverages, inspired by the rise in popularity of hard seltzers. There is an innovation in flavor blends to meet demand of customers in need of variety. Low-calorie and low-sugar options are being introduced for health-conscious consumers. Collaborations with other beverage producers are emerging, leading to exciting cross-category products.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Revolutionizing the Cider Industry Through E-Commerce and Digital Marketing
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: A strong online presence on social media, websites and e-commerce channels is a priority for cider producers. Direct-to-consumer sales strategies, which include online ordering and subscription services, are gaining traction. Virtual tastings, tours and events are on the rise, enabling consumers to have immersive brand experiences from home. Adoption of data-driven marketing strategies to offer personalized consumer experiences.

industry_definition: The Cider Production industry comprises companies primarily engaged in the production of alcoholic cider beverages. The production process consists of growing and harvesting apples, pears or other fruits; crushing and pressing the fruits into unfermented wort; and fermenting the blend into its finished product. The industry also includes companies and farms that produce nonalcoholic cider products.
key_trends: Cider producers have contended with volatile sales as small-scale brewers gain market share from one established brand. Angry Orchard has been the most well-known cider brand for a decade, but craft producers are shifting the landscape.
Craft cideries will continue emerging and shifting market dynamics. Small-scale producers will appeal to the rising demand for locally and sustainably made beverages.

A recent resurgence in the popularity of cider has prompted revisions of the regulatory framework surrounding hard cider. New cideries have emerged in droves, leaving no room for uncertainties around cider's legal definition.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market includes supermarkets, convenience stores and liquor stores. Cider outperformed many other beverage industries amid the pandemic in 2020 largely because of the retail channel. As on-premise drinking sites were forced to close, alcohol and beverage sales at grocery and liquor stores climbed. Many retailers who source their cider from local producers have seen a spike in sales as craft cider has gained popularity.

market_segmentation.segment: Wholesale Sales Dwindle as Craft Producers Expand
market_segmentation.segment_description: This market includes wholesalers that distribute cider to other wholesalers or to retailers. Wholesalers remain an integral market for cider producers thanks to the Three-Tier System, which mandates that producers sell alcoholic cider directly to wholesalers in participating states. Complex interstate distribution regulations also encourage producers to sell to wholesalers since it's more convenient. Craft cider producers are more inclined to sell their beverages directly to retailers and consumers since they operate on a more local level.

market_segmentation.segment: Food Service Sales Rebound From Pandemic Lows
market_segmentation.segment_description: This market includes restaurants, hotels and businesses. Direct shipments to licensed restaurants, hotels and other food service providers are legal in most states. When the pandemic shut down on-premise drinking sites, cider producers lost most of their demand from this market. Pent-up demand accompanying the vaccine rollout boosted food services' demand for cider.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes fermented alcoholic beverages made from the unfiltered juice of apples. Brewers develop a range of apple cider flavors by using various apples, spices and other flavorings. Apple is the original cider flavor and still dominates the market, although it has lost some sales to mixed fruit flavors.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Flavored Cider Expands as Younger Consumers Tire of Apple
products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes cider made from mixed fruits and other fruits besides apples, including pineapple, orange and passionfruit. The most popular alternative cider flavors include Ace Cider's Pineapple Cider, Incline Cider Company's Hopped Marionberry Cider and 2 Towns Ciderhouse's Pacific Pineapple Cider. Flavored ciders are rapidly gaining momentum as younger consumers seek new and alternative flavors.

This segment includes pear cider, known as perry, nonalcoholic ciders and apple cider vinegar. Sparkling ciders are popular for Thanksgiving or Christmas, while apple cider vinegar (ACV) is a year-round pantry staple. This segment has remained steady thanks to ACV's utility as a common cooking ingredient and sparkling cider's popularity with consumers who prefer nonalcoholic beverages.

tier_1_suppliers: Fruit & Nut Farming in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Cardboard Box & Container Manufacturing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Competition has intensified as younger drinkers increasingly seek alternative beverages. Cider has risen in popularity alongside hard seltzers and canned cocktails, both representing considerable competition.
Offbeat packaging can secure a spot on store shelves for smaller producers. Cideries compete fiercely for space on crowded shelves and must differentiate themselves somehow.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Imports Soar as Demand Overwhelms Small-Scale Domestic Cideries
international_trade_points.trade_description: Cider has a long history in Europe. The Cider Production industry is familiar with imports, which once satisfied nearly all of the domestic demand. As cider has gained popularity in the US, domestic producers have emerged to fulfill some of this demand. Still, foreign brands have developed brand loyalty and remain a fierce source of competition.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Imports Soar as Demand Overwhelms Small-Scale Domestic Cideries
international_trade_points.trade_description: When the pandemic struck, and domestic demand for cider experienced a sudden surge, many domestic craft cider producers fell short. These smaller-scale businesses couldn't quickly supply enough volume to satisfy the increased demand. This created a critical gap in the marketplace, subsequently filled by imports. Canadian cider, in particular, took advantage of this opportunity, stepping in robustly to quench the thirsty demand in the market. As such, Canada became a significant player in compensating for the deficits of the local US cider market during the pandemic.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Foreign Demand is Satisfied by Foreign Producers
international_trade_points.trade_description: Many of the US's biggest trading partners boast a mature, long-standing cider production industry. This vital industry foundation makes foreign consumers naturally gravitate towards well-known international brands. Consequently, with its less established identity, US cider suffers from lower demand as it grapples with these well-entrenched brand preferences in the global market.

There has been a significant influx of small-scale cideries that primarily cater to their local markets. This increase in local craft cider production has inadvertently led to a decrease in exports. The main reason for this trend is that these micro-cideries are not well-known abroad. Most of these small-scale cider makers focus on meeting the needs and preferences of their local clientele, with limited emphasis on international distribution.

business_locations.location_description: The Lake Effect Climate Makes the Great Lakes an Orchard-Filled Region. Michigan has more cideries than any other state, largely because of the state's abundant apple orchards. According to the USDA, Michigan is the third-largest apple producer in the US. Nicknamed the Fruit Belt, the Great Lakes region has a microclimate that moderates temperatures and makes for excellent fruit-growing conditions.

Washington state is the largest apple producer in the US. Temperate weather makes the West popular for cider producers, as warmer temperatures typically correlate with higher alcoholic beverage consumption. The West was home to some of the earliest craft brewers, leaving the region's residents hungry for more craft beverages.

New York state is a major hub for cider producers thanks to the state's many farms and orchards. Cider producers in the Mid-Atlantic have access to major urban centers, like New York and Philadelphia, providing an extensive pool of consumers. The region has a long history with apple-based liquors, with an early New Jersey distillery first producing Applejack in 1698.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE ALCOHOL AND TOBACCO TAX AND TRADE BUREAU (TTB)
regulations_points.regulation_description: For tax purposes, the Tax and Trade Bureau treats most cider like wine. Cider producers must register as a bonded winery, pay tax and follow other rules for winery operations, including labeling requirements. Some ciders can be taxed as beer, which has a different tax classification. The TTB regulates all facets of the production process of cider.

The Three-Tier System governs the distribution of alcohol in the US. Under the model, cideries must sell their products to wholesalers, which then sell to retailers, with no one entity allowed to engage in more than one tier. In control states, the state liquor commissions act as the wholesaler and often control the retail outlets. Small cideries that don't produce enough cider to negotiate cost-effective contracts with wholesalers are often disadvantaged by this system.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Industry assistance level is low and steady.
Competition level is high and increasing.

factors_decreased_barrier: New cideries that produce small batches can mitigate labor costs.

basis_points.basis_description: Competition has intensified as younger drinkers increasingly seek alternative beverages. Cider has risen in popularity alongside hard seltzers and canned cocktails, both representing considerable competition. Offbeat packaging can secure a spot on store shelves for smaller producers. Cideries compete fiercely for space on crowded shelves and must differentiate themselves somehow.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Familiar Cider Brands Grab Consumers' Attention
concentration_points.concentration_description: Angry Orchard, a division of The Boston Beer Company, revolutionized cider production after its inception in 2012. With its unique and versatile flavor profiles, it quickly gained popularity among consumers.

concentration_points.concentration_title: An Affinity for Local Products Attracts Small-Scale Cideries
concentration_points.concentration_description: Consumer preferences for smaller, independent businesses offering goods with locally sourced materials have expanded significantly, particularly in the niche market of cider production. The younger generation's constant exploration of new flavors and brands has been a major driving force, generating strong demand for innovative, small-scale cideries.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: PURCHASES STAY STEADY DESPITE EXPANDING INPUT COSTS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Increases in the price of fruit puts pressure on small-scale cideries. Still, cider producers often pass cost increases down to consumers, mitigating fluctuations in purchase costs. Cideries also establish contracts with suppliers to ensure a steady stream of inputs since they rely on consistent inputs to create the specific flavors of their ciders.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: AN INFLUX OF LABOR-INTENSIVE PRODUCERS INFLATES WAGES AND FLATTENS DEPRECIATION COSTS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Unlike their large-scale, big-brand competitors, small cider producers largely depend on manual labor, as implementing automated processes can be financially draining. The burgeoning scene of small-scale cideries has caused a sharp increase in wage costs due to the substantial reliance on a physical workforce.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: PROFIT SHRINKS AS SMALL CIDERIES FLOOD THE MARKET
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit margins vary considerably depending on a cidery's size and capital intensity. Over the past five years, several small-scale cider producers have emerged to meet the growing demand for local products. The average cider producer has between one and two employees in 2023, with many newer cideries being one-person operations.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Cider production requires significant manual labor, especially during the harvest season. New cideries that produce small batches can mitigate labor costs.

Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified. The spread of market segments suggests that there are limited entry points other than those already served by incumbent operators.

volatility_points.volatility_description: While the popularity of craft cider has been a boon for cider sales, more prominent national brands have struggled to maintain consumer interest. Consumer preferences for craft cider ebb and flow alongside per capita disposable income and the release of new flavors. Craft cideries with less capital than national brands have struggled to meet volatile demand.

As the pandemic shut down in-person operations, competing breweries struggled to stay afloat through strictly off-premise sales. Cideries are less dependent on in-person sales than breweries and ultimately benefited from the spike in off-premise alcohol purchases.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Apple Cider Remains the Frontrunner This segment includes fermented alcoholic beverages made from the unfiltered juice of apples. Brewers develop a range of apple cider flavors by using various apples, spices and other flavorings. Apple is the original cider flavor and still dominates the market, although it has lost some sales to mixed fruit flavors.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Flavored Cider Expands as Younger Consumers Tire of Apple
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: This segment includes cider made from mixed fruits and other fruits besides apples, including pineapple, orange and passionfruit. Many producers have experimented with alternative flavors and fruit types as hard apple cider has become popular. The most popular alternative cider flavors include Ace Cider's Pineapple Cider, Incline Cider Company's Hopped Marionberry Cider and 2 Towns Ciderhouse's Pacific Pineapple Cider.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Flavored ciders are rapidly gaining momentum as younger consumers seek new and alternative flavors.
Apple Cider Vinegar's Versatility in the Kitchen Keeps Sales Steady
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: This segment includes pear cider, known as perry, nonalcoholic ciders and apple cider vinegar. Sparkling ciders are popular for Thanksgiving or Christmas, while apple cider vinegar (ACV) is a year-round pantry staple. This segment has remained steady thanks to ACV's utility as a common cooking ingredient and sparkling cider's popularity with consumers who prefer nonalcoholic beverages.

FAQs.question: How's your company affected by rising imports?
FAQs.answer: Increases in domestic demand cause the value of imports to surge along with the quantity provided. Imports pose a significant threat to industry operators.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche or do you produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Most industry operators produce a variety of hard ciders. Smaller craft cider producers have entered the industry, specializing in different fruit and flavor varieties.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Many operators choose to grow their own apples to reduce purchasing costs and avoid volatile input costs. However, the cost of packaging material is generally slightly volatile, particularly the price of aluminum.

FAQs.question: Have you looked into setting up manufacturing facilities in lower-wage regions of the country?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators generally locate their establishments near important suppliers to reduce costs. Additionally, wages do not account for a large share of revenue; thus, operators do not focus on low-wage areas of the country.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technologies?
FAQs.answer: Many operators have utilized new automation technologies, particularly to improve quality control. Still, the industry as a whole has experienced a low level of technological change.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Small cider producers have invested heavily into capital and equipment that can ferment, bottle and package cider. However, the entrance of several new, small operators has increased wages' share of revenue.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: The Cider Production industry experiences a moderate level of regulation. The biggest regulatory expense for operators has been excise taxes; however, as this declines, operators benefit.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations, such as energy-efficiency standards?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators stay up-to-date with regulatory changes through several industry associations.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit varies significantly depending on an operators size and produce offerings. The largest operators in the industry are also major beer producers. As a result, these operators have the means to produce products for lower costs, resulting in far higher profit figures.

FAQs.question: What ongoing financing challenges does your company face?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators experience a very high level of both internal and external competition. Moreover, operators must attempt to predict consumers' interests as consumers continually seek out new and different alcoholic beverages.

FAQs.question: How do you attract and retain qualified staff? How do you keep wages competitive?
FAQs.answer: The hands-on and often technical nature of cider production requires extensive training and familiarity with cider flavor profiles.

FAQs.question: Do you have a reputation for good quality service? Do you manufacture any branded products?
How do you market your company's products to the general public? How does your advertising methods compare with that of your competitors?
FAQs.answer: The market for craft alcoholic beverages is increasingly saturated. It is vital that cider producers distinguish their product from their many competitors.

FAQs.question: Does international trade significantly affect your business? When the value of the US dollar rises, how are your operations affected?
FAQs.answer: The trade-weighted index (TWI) measures the strength of the US dollar relative to the currencies of its trading partners.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of slow growth in expenditure on alcohol? Do you closely how much is spent on alcohol?
FAQs.answer: The total level of alcohol consumption will have a significant effect on industry revenue. As alcohol consumption rises, competition from substitute alcoholic beverages rises as well.

FAQs.question: Do you track excise tax rates? How have trends in excise tax rates affected your business?
FAQs.answer: The US Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau categorizes cider as a type of wine, the production of which may be taxed as a result.
